description: From Middle English instrumental, instrumentale, from Medieval Latin īnstrūmentālis.

adjectives.description: instrumental (comparative more instrumental, superlative most instrumental)

entries.meaning: essential or central; of great importance or relevance.
examples: He was instrumental in conducting the business.

entries.meaning: Serving as an instrument, medium, means, or agency.
examples: Maxwell started back to his study, feeling that kind of satisfaction which a man feels when he has been even partly instrumental in finding an unemployed person a remunerative position.

entries.meaning: (music) Pertaining to, made by, or prepared for an instrument, especially a musical instrument (rather than the human voice).
(grammar) Applied to a case expressing means or agency, generally indicated in English by by or with with the objective.
(music) A composition written or performed without lyrics, sometimes using a lead instrument to replace vocals.
examples: I recommend this album in the face of the fact that five of the eleven songs are the purest filler, dull instrumentals with a harmonica rifling over an indifferent rhythm section. The rest is magnificent  […]
